title: In practice, how aggressive is a bankruptcy trustee in selling a person's such as bed or sofa?
question: Reviewing California bankruptcy law I was surprised to learn that furniture with a value of over ~$600 per piece can be seized by the bankruptcy trustee for sale.
answers:
In the 40 years I have been practicing law come December 2, I have handled thousands of cases. As a certified Consumer Bankruptcy Law Specialist and past chairman of the State Bar's Bankruptcy Advisory Commission, I can honestly say I have never seen a single stick of furniture sold or a single appliance sold.

A few years back, my firm had a case where a numbered print by Picasso was sold for approximately $15,000, but to the best of my recollection, that was one of the few times that any item of home furnishings was ever sold.

As my colleagues point out, practices vary throughout the United States, but here in the Central District of California where you are located, personal property is rarely sold by trustees. In a recent published decision by one of the bankruptcy judges, it was estimated that in 99% of all consumer cases no assets are administered by sale.

It's hard to beat those odds. So I would not worry about the bedroom set or the sofa.

It is not as simple as you try to make it sound. There are more factors that need to be considered other than the mere value of the furniture. As others have identified, household furniture depreciates astronomically once it is placed in use. If a Trustee wants to liquidate furniture, he has to pay for moving expenses to retrieve, store and sell the items. He normally would auction the items off, which the auctioneer typically receives a 15% commission (or more). He also has to pay you the exempt portion of the furniture, which often is the majority, if not all of the value of the furniture. He then has his Trustee's commission that he has to account for; and lastly, he needs to factor in some money to be paid to the Creditors. Then, he has to convince the Bankruptcy Judge that it was all worth his effort to take these steps. It's a complicated process, and that is why most Trustees are very skeptical about selling a person's household furniture unless it has some extrinsic value such as being of antique nature, etc. How much would you pay for the person's bed who lives five streets over from you? It's dirty, old, and disgusting to even think of it. For that reason most Trustee's aren't very agressive in this regard.

I have never seen it done in. Keep in mind that a couch may cost $4,000 on the furniture showroom floor but within six months or less in a person's home, it is used furniture that is worth less than $600 in almost every case.

I do not practice in California but have practiced in similar states with statutes granting exemptions for property less than $600 in value. A bankruptcy trustee has to justify the time spent liquidating assets and rarely administers personal property unless it's something rare, antique, or of substantial value. Most assets can be exempted using garage sale/pawn shop value, unless there is grounds for other value (like a car value through KBB or an insurance value of a piece of jewelry).

Furniture depreciates quickly so I really doubt most furniture is actually worth $600 unless it's brand spanking new.

Seek bankruptcy counsel for more information.

Usually, personal items, such as clothes and household furniture, will enjoy full protection. However, a gold plated kitchen table might attract special attention. Also, specialty items such as stamp collections or special items or heirlooms, must be declared, and can be evaluated on a case by case basis. There are specific exemptions, but those have value limitations.

The value given to furniture or clothing in a bankruptcy schedule is usually yard sale value, not the purchase price. Additionally, the age and condition are factors. You may also have what is called the "wildcard" exemption, which is over $20,000 to spread around various assets, to give them additional protection.

Good luck

You may have filed under the wrong exemption scheme or you don’t understand how exemptions apply to your case, should you file. Some states have their own exemption laws so don’t rely on an opinion from someone who doesn’t practice in that state.
